summary_points: 1. On May 28, 2025, CBRE Services, Inc. redeemed all outstanding $600 million of its 4.875% senior notes due 2026.
2. This 8-K filing reports the early redemption of $600 million in senior notes, resulting in the discharge of obligations for CBRE Services, Inc. and the parent company.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in this filing beyond the fact that the debt has been repaid.
1. On May 21, 2025, Cencora, Inc. appointed Lori J. Ryerkerk to its Board of Directors, effective June 1, 2025.
2. On May 27, 2025, Ornella Barra resigned from Cencora's Board of Directors due to Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc.'s (WBA) ownership falling below 5%.

3.  WBA's ownership falling below 5% in early June will result in them no longer being entitled to designate any directors to Cencora's Board, as per their Amended and Restated Shareholders Agreement.
1. The Home Depot's 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders was held on May 22, 2025, resulting in the election of a new Board of Directors and the ratification of KPMG LLP as the independent auditor.
2.  A shareholder proposal for an independent board chair received 193,933,942 votes for and 513,939,873 votes against, indicating significant shareholder opposition.
3. Shareholder proposals regarding biodiversity impact assessment and a report on packaging policies for plastics were both not approved at the May 22, 2025 meeting.
1. AutoZone Inc. appointed Constantino Spas Montesinos to its Board of Directors on May 28, 2025.
2. As of May 10, 2025, AutoZone operated a total of 7,516 stores across the U.S., Mexico, and Brazil.
3.  Mr. Montesinos' compensation will adhere to AutoZone's standard policies for non-employee directors, as detailed in the company's 2024 Definitive Proxy Statement.

1. DuPont de Nemours, Inc.'s annual stockholder meeting on May 22, 2025, resulted in the election of 13 nominees to the Board of Directors and the advisory approval of executive compensation, with  81.22% of outstanding shares voted.

2.  At the May 22, 2025 meeting,  the appointment of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for 2025 was ratified by a vote of 336,941,794 shares for, and 2,243,977 shares against.
3.  The filing indicates that as of March 31, 2025, there were 418,498,498 outstanding shares of DuPont's common stock.
1. On May 23, 2025, Robert Telesmanic announced his retirement as SVP, Controller, and Chief Accounting Officer, effective July 1, 2025; Alina Kerdman was appointed to replace him on May 28, 2025.
2. Ms. Kerdman's annual target compensation will be $1,200,000, including a $400,000 base salary, a $200,000 cash incentive target, and $600,000 in stock units.
3.  Ms. Kerdman will receive transition awards of RSUs and PSUs with a combined grant date fair value of approximately $200,411 to align her 2025 equity compensation with her new role.

1. At United Airlines Holdings, Inc.'s May 21, 2025 annual meeting, shareholders elected 11 directors nominated by the board, with varying levels of opposition ranging from minimal to significant (e.g., Edward M. Philip received 20,634,698 votes against his election).
2.  Shareholders rejected a proposal to remove the one-year stock ownership requirement for calling special meetings, with 192,439,319 votes against the proposal versus 43,763,344 votes in favor.
3. Ernst & Young LLP was ratified as the company's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.

1. At the May 28, 2025 annual meeting, Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. shareholders elected thirteen nominees to the Board of Directors and approved, on an advisory basis, the compensation of named executive officers and the selection of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.
2.  While all director nominees received a majority of votes cast, the votes against ranged from 776,068 to 12,348,338, indicating varying levels of shareholder support.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks were identified in this section of the filing.
1. As of April 30, 2025, the company had $194.3 million remaining available for stock repurchases under its suspended stock repurchase program.
2.  The company's cash equivalents and short-term investments totaled $877,957,000 as of April 30, 2025, a significant increase from $877,957,000 in October 31, 2024.

3.  The company's total borrowings were $10,050,643,000 as of April 30, 2025,  with a potential risk of mandatory redemption of certain senior notes by January 31, 2026,  at a 101% premium plus accrued interest if the Ansys Merger is not completed.
1. At Phillips 66's May 21, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, a proposal to declassify the Board of Directors over three years failed, with 295,250,873 votes for and 7,087,290 votes against.
2.  Shareholders approved, on an advisory basis, the compensation of the Company’s named executive officers, with 254,968,960 votes for and 42,326,860 votes against.
3.  A shareholder proposal requiring annual director resignations was rejected, receiving 99,489,243 votes in favor and 202,748,330 votes against.
1. Synopsys Inc. reported Q2 2025 revenue of $1.604 billion, exceeding the midpoint of its guidance and representing a year-over-year increase from $1.455 billion in Q2 2024.
2.  Synopsys reaffirmed its full-year 2025 revenue guidance and non-GAAP operating margin guidance as of May 28, 2025.

3. Synopsys anticipates Q3 2025 revenue in the range of $1.755 billion to $1.785 billion, and full-year 2025 revenue between $6.745 billion and $6.805 billion (these are forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ).

1. Nordson Corporation's second-quarter fiscal 2025 sales increased by 5% year-over-year to $683 million, driven by strength in electronics systems and partially offset by weakness in industrial systems sales.
2.  Adjusted earnings per diluted share for the second quarter of fiscal 2025 were $2.42, a 3% increase year-over-year.
3.  Nordson forecasts third-quarter fiscal 2025 sales to be in the range of $710 to $750 million and adjusted earnings to be between $2.55 and $2.75 per diluted share (as of May 28, 2025).
1. As of April 27, 2025, NVIDIA's investment in CoreWeave was reclassified from non-marketable to marketable equity securities due to public market trading.
2.  During the first quarter of fiscal year 2026, NVIDIA recorded a $2.3 billion inventory provision in cost of revenue, compared to $210 million in the same period of fiscal year 2025.

3.  NVIDIA anticipates commencing leases with future obligations of $7.4 billion between the second quarter of fiscal year 2026 and fiscal year 2030, primarily for data center and office operating leases.

1. Fortive Corp. announced a temporary trading blackout period for its employee benefit plans' Fortive Stock Fund, beginning June 27th, 2025, and ending during the week of July 6th, 2025, due to the planned separation of its precision technologies segment.
2. This blackout affects all plan participants and their beneficiaries, prohibiting transfers into or out of the Fortive Stock Fund for at least three consecutive business days.

3.  Due to the blackout, Fortive's directors and Section 16 officers will be subject to trading restrictions on Fortive common stock from June 27th, 2025 at 4:00 p.m. Eastern Time until during the week of July 6th, 2025, as mandated by Section 306(a) of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and Regulation BTR.
1.  NVIDIA reported Q1 Fiscal 2026 revenue of $44.1 billion, a 12% increase from the previous quarter and a 69% year-over-year increase (as of May 28, 2025).

2.  A $4.5 billion charge was incurred in Q1 Fiscal 2026 due to new U.S. government export licensing requirements for H20 products impacting China sales, resulting in $2.5 billion of unshipped H20 revenue.
3.  NVIDIA forecasts Q2 Fiscal 2026 revenue of $45.0 billion, plus or minus 2%, reflecting an approximately $8.0 billion loss in H20 revenue due to export control limitations (as of May 28, 2025).

1. HP Inc.'s fiscal 2025 second-quarter net revenue was $13.2 billion, a 3.3% increase from the prior year but below the previously anticipated range of $0.62 to $0.72 for GAAP diluted net EPS and $0.75 to $0.85 for non-GAAP diluted net EPS.
2. Year-over-year, GAAP diluted net earnings per share decreased by 31%, while non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share decreased by 13%.

3.  HP Inc. anticipates generating free cash flow in the range of $2.6 to $3.0 billion for fiscal 2025,  and expects to fully offset trade-related costs by Q4 of fiscal 2025, assuming current conditions persist.

1. At Verizon's May 22, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, 82.38% of outstanding shares were present;  shareholder proposals regarding climate lobbying alignment, lead-sheathed cable reporting, and discrimination in advertising services were all defeated.

2.  Of the 3,473,140,231 shares present at the meeting,  Hans Vestberg received the fewest votes for election to the Board of Directors (2,535,905,787), while Shellye Archambeau received the most votes against (117,302,244).
3. The advisory vote to approve executive compensation was approved, with 2,476,221,687 votes for and 269,995,941 votes against.
1. At the May 21, 2025 annual meeting, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.'s shareholders elected 11 board members and rejected a proposal regarding executive compensation.
2.  Shareholder votes for board member Dion J. Weisler were significantly lower (274,603,443 for vs. others above 290 million) compared to the other nominees.
3. A shareholder proposal to remove the one-year holding period requirement for calling a special meeting was not approved.

1. Insulet Corp's shareholders approved the Insulet Corporation 2025 Stock Option and Incentive Plan on May 22, 2025, replacing the 2017 plan and authorizing the issuance of up to 7,400,000 shares of common stock.

2.  The 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders on May 22, 2025, saw 93.04% of outstanding shares represented, with shareholder votes approving the new incentive plan and the appointment of Grant Thornton LLP as the independent auditor.

3.  The new equity agreements, approved May 21, 2025, include  Non-Qualified Stock Option Agreements, Restricted Stock Unit Agreements, Performance Stock Unit Agreements, and Restricted Stock Unit Agreements for Non-Employee Directors, all subject to detailed terms and conditions outlined in the filing.
1. On May 27, 2025, Trane Technologies entered into a new $1 billion senior unsecured revolving credit agreement, replacing a previous agreement that expires June 18, 2026.
2. The new credit agreement has a term extending to May 27, 2030.
3. The proceeds from the new credit agreement will be used for working capital, commercial paper programs, and general corporate purposes.
1. Agilent Technologies, Inc. reported Q2 2025 revenue of $1.67 billion, a 6.0% increase year-over-year (5.3% core growth), exceeding expectations despite a dynamic market.
2.  GAAP net income for Q2 2025 was $215 million ($0.75 EPS), down 29% year-over-year, while non-GAAP net income was $373 million ($1.31 EPS), up 7% year-over-year.
3. Agilent forecasts full-year 2025 revenue between $6.73 billion and $6.81 billion (3.4% to 4.6% reported growth, 2.5% to 3.5% core growth), and non-GAAP EPS between $5.54 and $5.61.
1. Salesforce reported record first-quarter fiscal 2026 revenue of $9.8 billion, an 8% year-over-year increase (as of April 30, 2025).
2.  Current remaining performance obligation (cRPO) increased 12% year-over-year to $29.6 billion (as of April 30, 2025).

3. Salesforce raised its full-year fiscal 2026 revenue guidance by $400 million to a range of $41.0 billion to $41.3 billion, reflecting a weaker U.S. dollar and incorporating a currency tailwind (as of May 28, 2025).
1. Evan M. Turtz, Senior Vice President, General Counsel, and Secretary of Trane Technologies plc, will retire later in 2025 following a transition period.
2.  The filing is an 8-K report submitted on May 28, 2025.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned beyond the planned retirement and transition of a senior officer.
1. At APA Corp's May 22, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, approximately 87% of eligible shares were voted.
2.  The election of directors (Proposals 1-11) saw significant variation in the number of votes cast against each nominee, ranging from approximately 2 million to over 8 million.
3. The non-binding advisory vote on executive compensation (Proposal 13) resulted in approval of the named executive officers' compensation, with 236,063,201 votes for and 45,671,250 votes against.
1. David Howson, Executive Vice President and Global President of Cboe Global Markets, resigned on May 27, 2025, effective August 1, 2025.

2.  Mr. Howson will receive his base salary and benefits until August 1, 2025, a pro rata portion of certain vesting restricted stock units, and a pro rata portion of performance-based restricted stock units (based on performance through the end of the applicable performance period), while forfeiting the remainder.
3. Following Mr. Howson's departure, Cboe's CEO, Craig Donohue, will also assume the title of President, effective August 2, 2025.
1. Equity Residential announced on May 28, 2025, that its senior management team will present at the Nareit REITweek 2025 Investor Conference on June 3, 2025.
2.  The company owns or invests in 312 properties with 84,648 apartment units as of May 28, 2025.
3.  An updated investor presentation, including operating and transaction updates, was posted to the company's website on May 28, 2025.

1. Boston Scientific Corporation discontinued worldwide sales of the ACURATE neo2™ and ACURATE Prime™ Aortic Valve Systems on May 28, 2025, due to increased clinical and regulatory requirements deemed prohibitive by the company.

2. Despite the discontinuation of ACURATE, the company expects to meet its previously issued second quarter and full year 2025 reported and organic sales and adjusted earnings per share guidance (as of April 23, 2025).
3.  The company is not reaffirming its GAAP EPS guidance (issued April 23, 2025) and will provide further information during its second quarter 2025 earnings call.

1. On May 28, 2025, Honeywell International Inc. entered a cooperation agreement with Elliott Investment Management, resulting in the appointment of Marc Steinberg as a new independent director to the Board, effective May 31, 2025.

2.  The agreement includes a standstill provision restricting Elliott from exceeding 4.9% beneficial ownership or 7.5% aggregate economic exposure to Honeywell's outstanding common stock until at least 30 days before the 2026 annual meeting nomination deadline.
3.  Mr. Steinberg's appointment to the Audit Committee and his receipt of the same compensation as other non-employee directors is effective from May 31, 2025.
1. On May 27, 2025, FMC Corp. sold $750,000,000 of 8.450% Fixed-to-Fixed Reset Rate Subordinated Notes due 2055.
2. The net proceeds will be used to redeem $500,000,000 of 5.150% Senior Notes due May 18, 2026, and for general corporate purposes.
3. The Indenture governing the Notes limits FMC Corp.'s ability to create liens, enter into sale and leaseback transactions, and merge or sell substantially all of its assets.

1. Elevance Health reaffirmed its full-year 2025 shareholders' earnings guidance to be $28.30 to $29.00 per diluted share, with adjusted earnings (excluding net unfavorable items) expected to be $34.15 to $34.85 per diluted share.
2. The company anticipates that 60% of its adjusted shareholders' earnings per diluted share will be realized in the first half of 2025.
3.  Elevance Health's guidance is contingent upon current market conditions and assumptions; changes to these factors could significantly alter actual results.
1. Home Depot's diluted earnings per share decreased by 5% year-over-year in Q1 2025, reaching $3.45.
2.  As of May 4, 2025, Home Depot had $11.7 billion remaining under its $15 billion share repurchase authorization, with repurchases paused since March 2024.
3.  Home Depot replaced three backup credit facilities with a new five-year $3.5 billion facility and a new 364-day $3.5 billion facility.

1. Ross Stores, Inc. held its annual meeting of stockholders on May 21, 2025, where all three proposals (election of directors, advisory vote on executive compensation, and ratification of Deloitte & Touche LLP) passed.
2.  Over 260 million shares voted "for" the election of each of the 11 director nominees, while "against" votes ranged from 3.9 to 20.4 million shares.
3.  Deloitte & Touche LLP was ratified as the company's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending January 31, 2026.
1. On May 27, 2025, Northrop Grumman Corporation priced a $1 billion debt offering, comprised of $500 million in 4.650% senior notes due 2030 and $500 million in 5.250% senior notes due 2035.

2.  The net proceeds from the offering are expected to be used for general corporate purposes, which may include debt repayment (including its 7.875% and 7.750% senior notes due 2026), share repurchases, and working capital.
3. The offering is expected to close on May 29, 2025, subject to customary closing conditions.
1. Equinix, Inc.'s May 21, 2025 Annual Meeting resulted in the approval of an amendment to their 2020 Equity Incentive Plan, increasing the number of reserved shares by 3.3 million.
2.  The stockholder proposal related to written consent of stockholders was not approved at the May 21, 2025 Annual Meeting, receiving only 28,881,879 votes in favor compared to 54,117,052 against.
3.  PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as Equinix's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.
1. On May 27, 2025, Builders FirstSource, Inc. stockholders approved amendments to declassify the Board of Directors and limit the liability of certain officers.
2. At the 2025 Annual Meeting, 91.01% of the voting power of Builders FirstSource, Inc.'s outstanding common stock was represented.
3.  A proposal to remove limits on the size of the Board of Directors was not approved by Builders FirstSource, Inc. stockholders at the 2025 Annual Meeting.
